name: 5-Minute Hummus
description: How do you improve on something that’s already pretty beloved? For starters, you could make it accessible without sacrificing quality. Michael Solomonov and Steven Cook of the Philadelphia restaurant Zahav found success with their hummus recipe, but in their second book, “Israeli Soul,” the two came up with this smart improvement, done in a fraction of the time of the original. It’s just as satisfying, and packed with tahini flavor, a given since it calls for a whole 16-ounce jar. (Another advantage? No leftover tahini languishing in the back of your fridge for months.) The end result is nutty and smooth, and topped with roasted vegetables, a worthy weeknight meal.
recipeCategory: dinner, easy, lunch, quick, snack, weekday, beans, dips and spreads

recipeInstructions.text: Drop the 1/4 garlic clove into a food processor and add the lemon juice. Pour the tahini on top, making sure to scrape it all out of the container, and add the salt and cumin. Process until the mixture looks peanut-buttery, about 1 minute. Stream in the ice water, a little at a time, with the motor running. Process just until the mixture is smooth and creamy and lightens to the color of dry sand.
Add the chickpeas and process for about 3 minutes, scraping the sides of the bowl as you go, until the chickpeas are completely blended and the hummus is smooth and uniform in color.
